text:
If you visit a non-existing URL using the HTTP Proxy, you'll get, instead of the
404 page, a response with no headers and the text "java.io.IOException" in the
body. This causes issues with some sites (e.g. http://hometown.aol.ca/ ), and
also prevents testing the 404 functionality (some sites have pretty complex
pages as 404 pages, which need to be tested too).

Even worse, the console output doesn't help finding out what the problem is. No
matter whether using the proxy or running a test, HTTP errors should at the very
least printed out on the console showing the URL, the error code and the error text.
creator: jsalvata@atg.com
mstover1@apache.org
text:
A trickier problem than I anticipated.  It appears Sun's HTTP Client is throwing
an exception when a 404 is returned, and I can't get access to the returned
data.  Java also is completely ignoring various try/catch blocks and throwing
exceptions right through them.

creator: jsalvata@atg.com
text:
Marking all bugs RESOLVED before JMeter 1.8's release date as VERIFIED.
Yes, it's pretty poor QA procedure, but there's bugs here lingering since JMeter
1.6, and we need to clean up a little.
Bulk-closing all bugs RESOLVED before JMeter 1.8 release date.
creator: jsalvata@atg.com
